title: Citigroup Losses Heighten Concerns over Economy
summary: Citigroup lost nearly $10 billion during the last three months of 2007, the company said Tuesday, attributing much of the loss to the subprime mortgage crisis that has been battering the U.S. banking sector for months. The news from the financial giant — in addition to news on inflation and weaker-than-expected retail sales numbers — hit the stock market hard, with the major indices losing more than 2 percent. It fell to Citigroup CEO

title: Debating the Merits of the Underdog Movie Formula
summary: brutality, including a harrowing lynching. In short, there is a lot of history up there on screen, but there's also a good deal of fictionalizing — composite characters, debate topics that are excessively on-point, even some inflation regarding Wiley's big showdown, which in real life was with the University of Southern California, not Harvard. Does this diminish the film? Well, that's, debatable I suppose. Certainly it makes The Great Debaters an unreliable

title: Iran, Demand and the Dollar Drive Up Oil Prices
summary: Crude oil prices are approaching uncharted territory. Until now, the high-water mark for oil prices has been April 1980. That's when Iran threatened to cut off oil supplies in the wake of a failed military raid aimed at rescuing Americans held hostage in Tehran. The price of West Texas Intermediate crude oil hit $39.50 that month. Adjusting for inflation, that's about $99 in today's dollars. It has taken more than

title: China's Effect on Dollar Reflects Growing Influence
summary: the world's largest foreign exchange reserves; they are participating in all of the international financial institutions, which they were absent from." And that integration has benefits for the United States. Cheap Chinese exports have helped keep inflation low, and China's purchase of treasury bonds has helped finance American debt. Still a Minor Fish in a Big Pond? For all of China's growing influence, some analysts say people overestimate its actual power. Albert

title: Syria Tries to Cope with Influx of Iraqi Refugees
summary: talk," she says. "We had enough — we don't want — it's not good for the Syrian people." Rime Alaf, a Syrian political analyst, says pressure has been building over the past year. "We're talking about inflation — an increase in rentals and in real estate, an increase in the price of most things — overcrowding in schools," Alaf says. "Overall, they realize it has affected them adversely." Some Syrians take advantage of the refugees, Alaf

title: Rise in Insurance Rates Slows, Kaiser Survey Says
summary: A new survey shows that an increase in health insurance rates this year is less than the increase last year. But, that's not necessarily good news to the employers or employees who pay the premiums. Every year, the Kaiser Family Foundation asks 2,000 small, medium and large businesses what they're doing about health insurance and how much they're paying. This year, businesses reported facing a 6 percent increase in health insurance

title: Pumping Money: Financial Market Liquidity Explained
summary: This week's frantic news from Wall Street sent central banks around the world pumping money into the financial system, providing liquidity, or ready cash. Adam Davidson talks to Debbie Elliott about what exactly this means. Let's say you own a big, beautiful $1-million house. The pizza delivery guy arrives with your dinner but you don't have any cash. He doesn't care how valuable your house is; he wants you to

title: Vintage Highlife and Afrobeat on 'Bokoor Beats'
summary: In Ghana, the '70s was a time of political repression, high inflation, and funky pop music. Among the musicians working the clubs in the Ghanaian capital, Accra, was a young British emigre named John Collins. Collins played guitar and harmonica, and even sang and composed with local bands. Later on, he became an important music producer in Ghana, where he still lives today. On Bokoor Beats, he compiles some of his favorite songs from his

title: Peres Seeks to Halt Iranian Nuclear Program
summary: In a Monday interview with NPR, Israel's new president, Shimon Peres, calls for a united international front to stop Iran's nuclear program, saying Iran's president "worships" a nuclear bomb more than he worships God. Peres has held nearly every senior post in Israel's government. At 83, he now has a new job: Peres is re-defining the parameters of the presidency, a traditionally ceremonial post. Many Israelis believe the country's

title: Turks Prepare to Head to the Polls
summary: Turks head to the polls on Sunday for parliamentary elections, just two months after protests by opposition parties and the Turkish military led to the annulment of presidential elections. The political crisis struck a blow to moderate Islamist Prime Minister Recep Tayip Erdogan, whose Justice and Development Party, or AK Party, as it is known in Turkey, is running for re-election after 4 ½ years in power. Heightened Voter Interest Normally, Turkey's Mediterranean

title: Zimbabwe's Economy Teeters Out of Control
summary: Melissa Block talks with John Robertson, an economist in Zimbabwe, about the situation there. Inflation is out of control, prices are through the roof and the country is experiencing a fuel shortage.

title: Injured Vets Hit Snags in Qualifying for Home Grants
summary: About 138,000 U.S. military members have been added to the Veterans Affairs Department's disability compensation rolls since 2001. Each year, a few hundred of them seek grant money from the VA to make their homes handicapped-accessible. But some veterans are finding they aren't eligible because their injuries aren't covered under the law, and they want Congress to do something about it. Navigating a Home Blind One serviceman whose injuries

title: Argentina's Unusual Approach Leads to Big Gains
summary: Argentina is back from the economic brink of 2001 that drove half the population into poverty and ruined the country's credit. President Nestor Kirchner, who could seek re-election this fall, is widely acknowledged as having guided South America's economic sick man back to health. The president's dose of orthodox medicine and not-so-orthodox intervention has also deepened his reputation as a maverick. Nine million people in Argentina still live below

title: U.S. Gasoline Prices Rise; the Highest Is in Chicago
summary: Gasoline prices have reached a new all-time high for the United States, as the average retail price for a gallon of regular gas is $3.23 a gallon, according to AAA. Adjusted for inflation, gas was slightly more expensive back in 1981. But if today's average goes up few more cents, it will break that record. Local prices varied widely, with a gallon going for less than $3 at some stations in New

title: Critics Urge Zimbabwe's Mugabe to Step Down
summary: Zimbabwe's government and party are in disarray and can no longer govern effectively, say the ruling party's critics, who include U.S. Ambassador Christopher Dell. Growing numbers within the country - as well as within his own government - want President Robert Mugabe to step down. Life has grown increasingly difficult for the average person in Zimbabwe, where unemployment is reaching 80 percent and inflation is higher than 1,700 percent. The government's recent

title: What Happened to Russian Democracy?
summary: When then-President Boris Yeltsin stood on a tank in 1991, waving a fist in defiance of communist hard-liners, he heralded a new dawn for Russia. The Soviet Union collapsed months later, promising to usher in a new era of Western-style democracy. But at the end of Yeltsin's rule, eight years later, democracy had become a dirty word for most Russians. President Vladimir Putin often is praised for bringing an end to

title: Life at GW: School's Yearly Fees Top $50K
summary: George Washington University in Washington, D.C., recently set the record for the highest cost for a year of education. Classes and room and board now run over $50,000 a year. Robert Siegel talks with Stephen Joel Trachtenberg, president of George Washington University, about the school's charges. The median household income in 2005, according to the Census Bureau was: $46,326 In the 1986-1987 academic year at George Washington, the cost of

title: National Economy Shows Muscle in Job Growth
summary: The labor market finished strong for 2006, posting an increase of 167,000 jobs for December, the Department of Labor reported Friday. The unemployment rate held steady at 4.5 percent. For all of 2006, employers added 1.8 million jobs to payrolls. That's a relief. Throughout last year, many economists worried that the cooling real-estate market could hurt job growth and tip the country into recession. After years of spiraling prices and

title: Wholesale Prices Surge; Economists Urge Calm
summary: New government figures show wholesale prices rose at a higher-than-expected rate of two percent last month. The data has raised new questions in the financial markets about inflationary pressures on the economy. The financial markets hate inflation. They also hate sudden and unexpected changes in economic conditions. So investors were caught off guard Tuesday morning by news that a key inflation measure rose at its fastest rate in three decades last month. But

title: Dodging Medicare Drug Plan Pitfalls
summary: choosing a plan based solely on a low premium, says Neuman of the Kaiser Foundation. "Premiums aren't necessarily a good indicator of the value of a product," Neuman says. Coverage costs in general are rising with inflation. Premiums are rising by an average of 10 percent, and deductibles -- the amount customers pay out-of-pocket before coverage begins -- are also increasing. For example, the 2006 maximum deductible of $250 will grow to $265 for

title: After Two Strong Quarters, GDP Swoons
summary: on a slump in the housing sector. As rough patches go, this one has arrived with unusual suddenness. Earlier this year, the economy was growing at better than 5.5 percent, and Federal Reserve officials worried about inflation pressures. Since then, interest rates have gone up, and job creation has been weak. Now, overall growth is what economists call "below-trend" -- meaning it is weaker than necessary to sustain a healthy economy. Joel Naroff, president

title: Signs That College Tuition Hikes May Ease a Bit
summary: The double-digit tuition hikes of recent years have slowed, though tuition is still rising faster than the inflation rate in some places, according to the College Board. The group has released its new report on tuition increases at U.S. public and private universities.

title: Economist Edmund Phelps Receives Nobel
summary: Robert Siegel talks with Columbia University professor Edmund Phelps, winner of this year's Nobel Prize for Economic Sciences. Phelps' work in the 1960s helped to better explain the relationship between inflation and unemployment, and had a profound impact on decisions made by corporate and government leaders.

title: Beset with Challenges, Lula Steers to the Middle
summary: so fundamentally unequal that, for the poor, even modest advances are milestones. At a recent graduation ceremony for 2,000 adults who just learned how to read, Lula touted booming exports, five million more jobs and low inflation that stretches the value of the minimum wage. He reaches his audience, many of them dependent on the minimum wage of approximately $150 dollars a month, with anecdotes that remind audiences in impoverished places that he is

title: U.S. Economy Adds Jobs; Unemployment Drops
summary: Employers added 128,000 jobs to their payrolls in August, and the unemployment rate fell to 4.7 percent. The Labor Department's monthly employment report presents a picture of an economy that is still expanding, but at a more moderate pace. Economists say the gradual slowdown indicates the Federal Reserve seems to be succeeding in keeping inflation in check without choking off job growth. Wall Street cheered the jobs report, as stocks rose on

title: Shopping for the Consumer Price Index
summary: The Bureau of Labor Statistics today released the monthly Consumer Price Index, a key economic indicator that tracks inflation. To track prices, the Labor Department sends out hundreds of people around the country to monitor prices for everything Americans buy -- from tires to food and college tuitions. Robert Siegel went shopping with Caren Gaffney to find out how the Consumer Price Index is compiled. On the outing, Gaffney, a former telecommunications executive, checked prices in

title: Suffering Persists After Zimbabwe Razing Campaign
summary: As Zimbabwe's economy collapses under 1,000 percent inflation, many of the people uprooted by a slum-clearance campaign last year remain homeless and unemployed. Human-rights activists in the Southern African nation say the country is on the verge of social upheaval. A year ago in May, the government of Zimbabwe launched a weeks-long, urban cleanup drive called Operation Murambatsvina. Police and soldiers swept through the slums of Zimbabwe's cities, destroying

title: Fed Stays Vague on Future Rate Increases
summary: The Federal Reserve decides Wednesday to raise its key short-term interest rate to 5 percent. That much was expected. But Fed remained vague about the likelihood of future rate increases. "Some" increase in rates "may yet be needed to address inflation risks," the Fed said. Robert Siegel talks with Jack Speer.

title: Greenspan Era At The Fed Comes To A Close
summary: After more than 18 years at the helm of the nation's economy, Alan Greenspan steps down next Tuesday. As chairman of the Federal Reserve, Greenspan presided over the longest economic expansion in U.S. history. He also successfully navigated several financial storms including the stock market crash of 1987. His record has earned him a reputation as one of the best central bankers ever. Greenspan's steady hand on the tiller through boom times

title: Bernanke Vows to Continue Greenspan Policies
summary: Ben Bernanke, President Bush's pick to succeed Alan Greenspan as Federal Reserve chairman, tells lawmakers he would seek to maintain continuity with Greenspan's policies. Bernanke also said he would not pursue a specific inflation target without building consensus for change in the existing policy.

title: China Pressured by High Gas Prices
summary: The Chinese government is feeling the unprecedented political pressure of rising prices at the gas pump. This summer has seen shortages and long. But the government is wary of lifting price controls, fearing inflation and unrest among taxi drivers and farmers who rely on gas.

title: Federal Funds Rate Hits 3.5 Percent in 10th Increase
summary: The Federal Reserve raises a key interest rate one quarter of a percent, the tenth consecutive quarter-point rate hike. In making the target for federal funds 3.5 percent, the Fed is continuing its efforts to balance a growing economy with low inflation.

title: Oil Prices Close Above $60
summary: Oil prices move past $60 a barrel on signs that higher prices are doing little to discourage demand. U.S. crude for August delivery closed at $60.45, a new high in dollar terms, but nowhere near the inflation adjusted record.

title: The Willingness to Work for Solutions
summary: I believe that the world is inherently a very dangerous place, and that things that are now very good can go bad very quickly. I stood recently at Checkpoint Charlie and I saw where the Berlin Wall had once been, where millions had lived in slavery only 20 years ago and I realized that it could happen again. I've stood at Auschwitz, where millions were massacred. Then I read about in Darfur, where hundreds

title: Fed Raises Rates, But Mortgage Rates Stay Low
summary: The Federal Reserve again has boosted the cost of borrowing for millions of consumers by raising short-term interest rates. Tuesday's quarter-point hike -- the eighth since June 2004 -- bumps a key bank lending rate to 3 percent. In its announcement, the Fed said spending growth has slowed somewhat, partly in response to higher energy prices, but it noted that inflation pressures have picked up in recent months. "It's very unusual for long

title: Ben Berman's Return to Flight
summary: Imagine losing the job you always wanted. That happened to Ben Berman. He was among the thousands of pilots laid off by the airlines after Sept. 11, 2001. During 3 1/2 years of waiting to return to the cockpit, he found a research job with NASA and kept up his piloting skills as a flight instructor in small airplanes. In his first-person account, Berman describes how, against the odds, he managed to find

title: Energy Costs Drive Key Price Index Upward
summary: Rising energy costs are pushing up the official inflation gauges. The consumer prices index was up sharply in February and gas prices have continued rising since then. According to the Energy Department, the average price for gas is now $2.10 a gallon.

title: Federal Reserve Raises Interest Rate
summary: The Federal Reserve raises a key short-term interest rate another quarter of a point, in an attempt to keep inflation under control as the economy continues to show signs of improvement. NPR's Jim Zarroli reports.

title: Spike in Producer Prices Surprises Analysts
summary: Inflation at the wholesale level shot up last month, rising 1.7%. That's the biggest increase in years and was well above what most analysts on Wall Street were expecting. Food and energy prices both fueled the increase. NPR's Jim Zarroli reports.

title: Fed Raises Short-Term Interest Rate
summary: As expected, Federal Reserve policymakers raise a key short-term interest rate by one quarter of a percentage point. The Fed Funds rate stands now at 1.5 percent. In a statement, the Fed said that while growth and job creation have slowed, "the economy nevertheless appears poised to resume a stronger pace of expansion going forward." Fed policymakers reiterated their belief that with inflation still relatively low, interest rates can be raised "at a

title: Fed Move Would End Period of Cheap Borrowing
summary: Federal Reserve policy-makers will likely approve a small increase in the short term interest rates it controls. The economy has been heating up and the Fed wants to keep inflation from getting out of hand. If the Fed does move tomorrow it will mean that a long period of historically low interest rates is coming to an end. NPR's Jim Zarroli reports.

title: Consumer Prices on the Rise
summary: Consumer prices for many goods and services have begun to rise as the nation's economic recovery gains momentum. The uptick in inflation has already pushed up mortgage interest rates, and could prompt the Federal Reserve to hike short-term interest rates by the summer. NPR's Jack Speer reports.

title: Greenspan: Consider Social-Security Cuts
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan tells lawmakers the nation's long-term budget situation has worsened to the point that cuts in social security benefits should be considered. Greenspan also reiterated his belief that lawmakers should increase the retirement age and end the practice of using the inflation rate to adjust social security payments. NPR's Jack Speer reports.

title: Zimbabwe's Problems Mount Under Mugabe
summary: In Zimbabwe, the policies of President Robert Mugabe are blamed for the world's highest inflation rate and for a drop in life expectancy. Mugabe's opponents are renewing efforts to challenge his authority. NPR's Jason Beaubien reports.

title: Fed Warning Sparks Deflation Fears
summary: The Federal Reserve's top policymakers warned of a possible "unwelcome substantial fall in inflation," raising fears of deflation. Cary Leahey, a senior economist at Deutsche Bank Securities, explains what deflation is, and why it could be bad for the economy.

title: Service Medals
summary: NPR's Michele Norris talks about military medals with David Riley of the Orders and Medals Society of America. He is the author of the book Uncommon Valor: Decorations and Service Medals. Riley talks about how military medals and honors are awarded, the problem of "medal inflation" and how military technology is changing the kinds of medals which are awarded to servicemen.

title: Zimbabwe
summary: NPR's Jason Beaubien reports Zimbabwe's economy -- once one of southern Africa's most vibrant -- is on the verge of collapse. Inflation is running at 200 percent, and Zimbabweans are forced to wait in long lines for basic goods. Government-ordered price controls have only made matters worse.

title: Real Estate
summary: NPR's Scott Horsley reports the National Association of Realtors predicted today this will be a record year for home sales. The association expects home prices will continue to increase at more than three times the rate of inflation. The rapid run-up in home prices has prompted comparisons to the stock market bubble of the late 1990s. But most experts say there's little chance of home prices crashing the way stocks have.

title: President Outlines Spending Plans
summary: President Bush laid out his first full-dress federal budget today, with a bottom line of more than $2 trillion and the biggest increase in military spending in 20 years. Driven by foreign fighting expeditions and heightened anxiety over homeland security, the budget calls for all other federal functions to make do with increases slightly below the rate of inflation. NPR's Don Gonyea reports from the White House.

title: Greenspan Report
summary: NPR's John Ydstie reports that Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan told lawmakers today that inflation is still well-contained and that recent increases in wholesale and consumer prices are mere blips on the screen. Greenspan was asked whether the Fed had waited too long before moving to cut interest rates in late January. Greenspan defended the central bank's actions and said the answer to the question is "No."

title: Fed Meeting
summary: NPR's Jim Zarroli reports the Fed left interest rates alone today but warned that higher energy prices and eroding consumer confidence are contributing to economic weakness. The Fed dropped its bias toward raising the key short-term interest rates it controls, saying economic weakness is now a greater risk than inflation.

title: Greenspan
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan said today that the central bank is being watchful for any signs that the economy is slowing sharply, suggesting that he may be willing to cut interest rates next year. As NPR's John Ydstie reports, stocks rallied sharply after Greenspan's speech. The Fed chairman indicated that he no longer sees higher inflation as the main threat to the economy.

title: Economy
summary: The U.S. economy is slowing down from its red-hot growth of the past few years. As NPR's John Ydstie reports, most economists believe the economy is in fine shape, growing at a sustainable level without significant inflation. But some worry that there are enough trouble spots -- declining corporate profits, a cheerless stock market and uncertainty over the presidential election -- to throw the economy into recession.

title: Greenspan
summary: Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan said today that surging oil prices bear close attention because they have the potential to disrupt the nation's longest ever economic expansion. As NPR's John Ydstie reports, Greenspan said higher oil prices have not sparked a new round of inflation, but that possibility still exists, especially given low inventories and tensions in the Middle East. He noted that federal budget surpluses have aided the expansion, but added

title: Direct Contracting
summary: NPR's Patty Neighmond reports on the trend by the nation's largest corporations and the government to contract directly with physicians -- leaving the insurance companies out. It's a move to stem double-digit inflation in health care costs.

title: Economy - GDP
summary: NPR's John Ydstie reports that once again the economy has outperformed expectations. The nation's gross domestic product increased five-point-two-percent in the second quarter, a much faster pace than most economists expected and a bit faster than growth in the first quarter. But even as overall growth sped up, inflation cooled off.

title: Greenspan
summary: NPR's John Ydstie reports Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan gave an upbeat assessment of the U.S. economy today. Greenspan told members of the Senate Banking Committee the economy shows signs of slowing to a more sustainable pace and that reduces the risk of accelerating inflation. Stock and bond markets both rallied on the suggestion that Fed might leave interest rates alone when it meets next in August.

title: Economy
summary: Inflation remained in check last month as consumer prices rose at the same pace as in five of the past six months. As NPR's Jack Speer reports, core prices rose just two-tenths of a percent last month, when food and energy prices are NOT taken into account. Even though gas prices escalated sharply in June, many economists see inflation remaining tame and believe the Federal Reserve is successfully engineering a "soft landing" for

title: Clinton Addresses Prescription Drugs
summary: No sooner had Republican leaders signaled their interest in drug prices than President Clinton called a news conference to reclaim the issue. At the White House today, Clinton presented a study by an advocacy group saying the prices of drugs that older Americans use most are rising faster than inflation. Clinton wants to expand current spending to provide prescription drug benefits for all Medicare recipients, while Republicans prefer an insurance-based solution. NPR White House

title: Market Day
summary: Financial markets regained their bearings today following last week's ghoulish selloff. All the major stock averages were up modestly in mid-afternoon trading as investors looked at battered stocks and saw a buying opportunity. But Wall Street remains on edge, especially over renewed signs of inflation. NPR's Jim Zarroli has a report.

title: Markets
summary: Battered financial markets absorbed another nasty blow today when the government reported that core consumer prices rose in March at their fastest monthly pace in more than 5 years. The signs of accelerating inflation sent all three major stock averages tumbling sharply, with the Nasdaq falling hardest. The index this week suffered one of the fastest downturns in market history. NPR's Jim Zarroli reports.

title: Interest Rates
summary: As expected, the Federal Reserve Board's open market committee raised a key interest rate a quarter point today, the Fed's fifth rate increase since June. NPR's John Ydstie reports that the Fed remains concerned that inflation could be the skeleton lurking in the economy's closet. Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan has repeatedly said that excessive consumer demand, sparked by stock market wealth, could undermine the nation's longest economic expansion.

title: Interest Rates
summary: As expected, the Federal Reserve Board's Federal Open Markets Committee hiked a key interest rate by a quarter of a point today in an effort to steady the nation's sizzling economy. Stock prices quickly fell sharply, a sign that investors fear that an inflation warning accompanying today's announcement means the Fed is not done raising rates. NPR's Jack Speer has the story.

title: Economy
summary: Robert talks with Adam Posen, a Senior Fellow at the Institute for International Economics, about the booming U.S. economy which is in the midst of the longest expansion in history. Posen says the only comparable period of expansion was in the sixties, which ended because of inflation and recession.

title: Sizzling Economy
summary: NPR's Jack Speer reports the economy ended 1999 with a strong performance. The Commerce Department says the nation's GDP, the gross domestic product, grew at a strong-than-expected 5-point-8-percent annual rate in the final three months of 1999. A separate report on employment costs showed signs that inflation may be picking up.

title: U.S. Economy
summary: NPR's Jim Zarroli reports the U.S. economy appears to be doing extremely well at the end of the year. Two reports out this morning suggest a strong holiday season for retailers and only modest price increases for consumers. In the bond market, fears the economy may be overheating trumped a very positive inflation report and prices slumped.

title: Market Surge
summary: NPR's Jim Zarroli reports that the major stock indices soared today, reaching or approaching new records, as an inflation-free jobs report convinced investors that the Fed won't be raising interest rates again anytime soon.

title: Interest Rates
summary: NPR's Jim Zarroli reports the Federal Reserve Board today raised interest rates for the third time this year, in an effort to head-off inflationary pressures on the economy. The Fed raised the federal funds rate -- the rate banks charge one another on overnight loans -- by a quarter point. It also raised the discount rate by a quarter point. The Fed's statement acknowledged there is little apparent sign of inflation presently, but indicated

title: Unemployment
summary: The nation's jobless rate has fallen to 4-point-1 percent, the lowest level in 29 years, as the freewheeling economy continued to create jobs in record numbers. NPR's John Ydstie reports stock and bond markets cheered the jobs report because it showed wages growing at very modest levels. That means inflation remains in check, and the Fed may not be tempted to raise rates at its next meeting.

title: Economy
summary: NPR's John Ydstie reports the U.S. economy turned in another solid performance in the third quarter, growing at an impressive 4.8% clip without generating higher inflation. The Commerce Department report showed growth accelerating sharply from the second quarter. A separate report from the Labor Department showed employer's labor costs rising slowly, even though the job market remains tight.

title: Market Gold Rush
summary: NPR's Kathleen Schalch reports that gold, written off recently as a not- so-precious metal from a bygone economic age, has made a surprising comeback. Its price per ounce surged 15 percent in a week, before drifting a bit lower. Is gold's jump a temporary blip -- European central banks are limiting their gold reserve sales -- or are jittery investors bailing out of stocks in favor of precious metals as a hedge against inflation?

title: Fed - Interest Rates
summary: NPR's John Ydstie reports that the Federal Reserve raised two key interest rates by a quarter point today in a move designed to put the kibosh on early signs of inflation. Though it was the second straight month the Fed increased its benchmark Federal funds rate, investors reacted positively, pushing up stock prices. They're hopeful that the Fed is finished raising rates for the year, and the economic boom will continue.

title: Consumer Price Index
summary: Consumer prices rose modestly in July, soothing fears that the Federal Reserve Board will aggressively hike interest rates to stamp out early signs of inflation. NPR's John Ydstie reports that the three-tenths of a percent gain in the consumer price index was in line with expectations.

title: Economy
summary: NPR's Snigdha Prakash reports that labor costs shot up in the second quarter, spooking the markets again about inflation, and raising the specter of more interest rate hikes. Stocks tumbled on all major markets. The news overshadowed a somewhat contradictory report that economic growth slowed considerably in the second quarter, with consumers slowing their pace of spending.

title: Fed - Interest Rates
summary: The Federal Reserve Board raised a key interest rate a quarter of a point today, attempting to forestall inflation and keep the economic expansion from overheating. The Federal Funds rate is now at five-percent. The move was expected. But many investors were surprised by the Fed's neutral stance towards future interest rate hikes. The board had been expected to lean towards a need for further tightening. NPR's Jim Zarroli reports.

title: Drug Costs
summary: On the eve of President Clinton's expected announcement of a plan to revamp the federal Medicare program, NPR's Patricia Neighmond looks at the rising price of prescription drugs. Inflation in that segment of the health care industry continues to outpace price rises for all other medical services and goods. Some economists say that may not be so bad, since new drugs are making people far more productive by lowering disability rates and lengthening

title: Greenspan
summary: Though inflation remains in check, Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan told a joint congressional committee that "preemptive" action by the Fed may be needed to protect the strong US economy. NPR's Jim Zarroli reports that relieved financial markets interpreted the remarks to mean that only a modest interest rate hike will follow later this month.

title: Market
summary: Last month's consumer prices increased by the largest amount in nine years.The unexpectedly large increase in inflation spooks Wall Street. NPR's Elaine Korry reports on the markets' reaction.

title: Unemployment
summary: NPR'S Jim Zarroli reports the U.S. economy continued to add jobs at a robust pace in February, according to the monthly unemployment report released today by the Labor Department. U.S. businesses added some 275-thousand jobs during the month, but there was only a slight increase in average hourly earnings and that helped ease investors about inflation. Both stock and bond prices shot up today.

title: Oil Prices
summary: The Commanding Heights: The Battle Between Government and the Marketplace That is Remaking the Modern World." They discuss how the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries lost control over the price of oil worldwide. Oil is now at its lowest price since 1933. Gasoline, once the price has been adjusted for inflation, is the cheapest it has ever been. They talk why and how this happened. (Note: "The Commanding Heights" is published by Simon & Schuster.)

title: The Night Before Macy's
summary: NPR's Margot Adler reports on what used to be one of New York's better-kept secrets, but which has now become a pre-parade ritual . . the inflation of the big balloons for Macy's traditional Thanksgiving Day Parade. The night before the parade, crowds now gather to watch their favorite characters come to life through the magic of helium.

title: Protests Planned For Moscow
summary: NPR's Michele Kelemen reports from Moscow on the nationwide protests expected tomorrow against President Boris Yeltsin. The protests have been organized by the Communist Party to demonstrate their lack of confidence in Yeltsin's handling of Russia's economic crisis. But even with a weakened ruble and soaring inflation, Kelemen reports that on the eve of the planned protests, Russians seem more apathetic than angry.

title: Brazil Election
summary: NPR's Mike Shuster reports from Sao Paulo that Brazilians go to the polls Sunday to elect a president. Incumbent Fernando Henrique Cardoso is far ahead in the polls, despite an economic crisis that threatens to plunge the nation into a severe recession. Many among the poor and working class will vote to give Cardoso another term because he was the architect of the successful fight against hyper-inflation.

title: Primakov Plan
summary: weeks after his confirmation as prime minister, Yevgeny Primakov has announced his plan to rescue Russia from economic collapse. Primakov pledged to pay soldiers and workers back wages and to index salaries and pensions to inflation. He also promised tax breaks for industrial investment and greater state control over alcohol production and sales. Analysts say Russia's central bank will almost certainly have to print more rubles to accomplish these goals, which will fuel inflation.

title: World Economy
summary: Linda talks with Walter Russell Mead, a senior fellow on US Foreign Policy and a political economist at the Council on Foreign Relations. They discuss President Clinton's proposal for an international conference on the global economy. Mead says that it is time to shift attention from the problems inherent to inflation to the issues that surround deflation, which he claims is more dangerous.

title: Cut Interest Rates?
summary: NPR's John Ydstie reports the Federal Reserve is under growing pressure to answer the turmoil in world markets with an interest rate cut. Economists are split on the issue, but some are saying it's time for the Fed to stop worrying about inflation at home and start worrying about economic threats abroad. Others say the Fed shouldn't do anything until it's clear the market turmoil is affecting the underlying economy.

title: Russians On Economy
summary: David McGuffin reports from Moscow that one day after the Russian government announced a de facto devaluation of the ruble, Russian citizens continued to line up at currency exchanges for dollars and deutschmarks. Others are rushing to make essential purchases before inflation pushes prices higher. While opposition politicians are calling for the resignation of President Yeltsin and the government, the President remains out of view.

title: Gdp Report
summary: The economy grew at a brisk rate in the first quarter, without even a hint of inflationary pressure. The gross domestic product expanded at a 4.2% annual rate, according to the Commerce Department. A separate report on employment costs also showed inflation to be well under control. The financial markets found the reports reassuring. Stocks surged while interest rates came down slightly. NPR's John Ydstie reports.

title: Social Security
summary: NPR's John Ydstie reports the strong economy has pushed back the point at which the Social Security system is expected to slip into insolvency. The retirement system's Board of Trustees says a growing economy, reduced unemployment and low inflation will keep the program solvent until 2032, three years longer than the previous estimate. While good news, the extension doesn't change the long-term problem of providing full benefits to the baby-boom

title: Greenspan
summary: NPR's John Ydstie reports that Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan delivered his semi-annual economic forecast to Congress today. The Fed Chairman predicts moderate and balanced growth this year and that policymakers expect the fallout from Asia to keep inflation in check. However, Greenspan also said there is a higher level of uncertainty than usual.

title: Lop Off A Few Zeros Comrade
summary: The Russians plan to erase three zeros from the ruble beginning tomorrow morning. A pair of blue jeans that cost 400-thousand rubles today, will cost 400 rubles tomorrow. David McGuffin reports from Moscow that the government has been planning the currency overhaul for six months. It wants the re-denomination to be seen as a symbol of the government victory over inflation...an inflation that peaked at a thousand percent a year in 1992

title: .] [Holiday Retail Health]
summary: NPR's Larry Abramson reports that the holiday shopping season has, so far, not lived up to retailers' hopes. With one week to go in the season, spending increases have at least kept up with inflation, but some stores wanted to see even bigger profits. The Christmas season is traditionally the most important time of year for retailers.

title: Deflation Scenario
summary: NPR's John Ydstie reports the nation's economy expanded at a 3.5% annual rate in the third quarter. Inflation remained subdued, growing at the slowest rate in more than thirty years. Inflation is now so low that some economists are warning that the U.S. faces a greater threat from falling prices than from prices that rise too quickly.

title: Congo Economy
summary: NPR's Jennifer Ludden reports from Kinshasa on efforts to begin rebuilding the devastated economy of the former Zaire. More than three decades of corruption and mismanagement under Mobutu Sese Seko left the vast central African nation with virtually no infrastructure. Laurent Kabila has moved to control inflation and fight corruption since taking power in May, but he faces a daunting task trying to overcome Mobutu's legacy.

title: Cpi & Ppi
summary: NPR's Elaine Korry reports that economic data released this morning show prices rising at the slowest pace in more than a decade. The consumer price index was up 0.2% in July. That's up from 0.1% in June, but so far this year inflation is running at a scant 1.5% pace. The bond market reacted favorably to news that inflation remains under control.

title: Dow
summary: NPR's Jim Zarroli reports the market gave investors a wild ride today. The Dow was down more than 200 points at one time, but then recovered. Broader market indices were also down and the Nasdaq composite lost ground as well. Analysts pointed to a sinking bond market and fears that inflation may be reviving.

title: Jobless Rate
summary: NPR's John Ydstie reports that unemployment slipped down another notch in May to 4.8%. Unemployment remains at its lowest point in more than 23 years. The report included signs that wages are on the rise, but analysts differed on whether the wage increases would lead to higher inflation.

title: The Fed
summary: NPR's John Ydstie reports the Federal Reserve Board has decided NOT to raise interest rates. The decision comes after a number of key indicators have shown that inflation remains low, and economic growth continues.

title: Dow Drops
summary: NPR's Jim Zarroli reports the stock market fell sharply on signs of renewed inflation. The Dow lost more than 140 points today, which leaves it down more than 600 points from its peak in March... and below where it started the year.

title: Market Week
summary: NPR's Jim Zarroli reports the nation's unemployment rate fell a tenth of a point in March to 5.2%. Analysts said today's report reinforced the picture of a strong economy that has all the necessary preconditions for inflation. The financial markets reacted negatively for the most part... as the Dow Jones Industrial Average declined for yet another day.

title: Fed
summary: Commentator Robert Kuttner says the policy of the Federal Reserve -- raising interest rates to ward off future inflation -- is perverse. He says inflation is lower this year than it was in 1996. Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan worries that a tight labor market means workers will be able to win salary hikes in the future. Kuttner predicts the addition of former welfare recipients to the labor force will actually hold wages down. He concludes the Fed

title: Greenspeak
summary: In testimony on Capitol Hill today, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan laid the groundwork today for possibly raising interest rates when the Fed meets next week. Greenspan said there are signs that inflation could rebound, and that the Fed must be proactive in snuffing out any signs of inflation with a rate hike. But lawmakers were not convinced that a rate hike is really necessary, given steady economic growth and stable inflation numbers. NPR's

title: Jobless Claims
summary: benefits took a dramatic drop last week. That put the four-week jobless claims average at an eight-year low. The nation's unemployment rate fell to 5.3% in February, amid strong job creation. The survey of business payrolls showed a net increase of 339,000 jobs for the month, far more than was expected. The stock and bond markets reacted favorably because there was little hint of any inflation in the new numbers.

title: Greenspan Talks
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan gave his semi-annual report today on the state of the U.S. economy and U.S. monetary policy. Greenspan delivered an upbeat assessment of the U.S. economy but voiced a warning about soaring stock prices and the risk of higher inflation. He said he could not rule out a pre-emptive hike in interest rates to hold economic growth and prices in check. NPR's John Ydstie reports.

title: Cpi Commission
summary: NPR's John Ydstie reports that Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan encouraged the Congress to move forward on efforts to revise the nation's main inflation guage, the consumer price index. Greenspan reiterated his view that the CPI overstates inflation and forces the government to overcompensate retirees and others for the effect of inflation.

title: Fujimori & Peru Crisis
summary: Jon Miller reports from Lima on how the hostage crisis has come at a crucial time for President Alberto Fujimori. The president had been hugely popular for beating back inflation and largely defeating Peru's two rebel armies, even though he had taken such drastic measures along the way as disbanding Congress. But Fujimori's popularity had been plunging this year as Peru's economy took a downturn, and the takeover of the Japanese ambassador

title: Cpi
summary: A special commission set up by Congress to study the accuracy of the consumer price index has concluded the C.P.I. overstates inflation by approximately 1.1%. The commission, headed up by former Bush Administration economic advisor, Michael Boskin, made several recommendations for correcting the upward bias...which costs the federal government billions of dollars every year because the C.P.I. is used to adjust benefit payments to millions of American retirees and

title: Stock Market
summary: The stock market rally that began just before the election still has some strength. The Dow Jones Industrials were up again today...the eighth day in a row the blue-chip index has set new record. Market analysts cite many factors, including the lack of any threat of inflation. NPR's Jim Zarroli has the details.

title: Dow 6000
summary: NPR's Jim Zarroli reports from New York, where the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained more than fifty points today, amid moderate economic growth and low inflation rates. He talks with Robert about what this means for investors and for the nation's economy...and whether or not the market is expected to continue its rise.

title: Census Figures
summary: The Census Bureau today reported that Americans' income edged up last year for the first time in six years and fewer families are living in poverty. The report, hailed by President Clinton, showed median household income of $34,076 in 1995, up 2.7 percent from 1994. The agency said this is the first real increase in six years after adjusting for inflation. NPR's John Nielsen has the details.

title: Mexico Bailout
summary: NPR's David Welna reports that President Clinton's controversial twenty-billion-dollar bailout of Mexico is succeeding. The 1995 package helped Mexico hold to a free market strategy, and now unemployment and inflation are going down, and the economy is showing signs of a comeback. Mr. Clinton has not made the bailout's success an issue in the campaign, however... his aides fear any mention of Mexico will remind voters about drug trafficking and

title: About Those Bonds...
summary: Robert talks with NPR's John Ydstie about how the new inflation-indexed treasury bonds will work, who they will appeal to and whether they are likely to increase national savings as the Clinton Administration hopes.

title: With Clinton
summary: At a campaign rally outside Pittsburgh today, President Clinton backed two proposals designed to appeal to middle class voters. One encourages long term savings with inflation-indexed securities; the other allows for tax-deductible interest on certain education savings bonds. NPR's Mara Liasson reports.

title: Econ-Wrap
summary: NPR's John Ydstie reports that an unemployment report released today suggested that economic growth in the U-S is slowing. There had been concern that the growing economy would spark high inflation.

title: Market
summary: NPR's John Ydstie reports the stock market was unusually volatile today...losing more than 160 points today before recovering. Positive news on inflation and industrial production did little to calm jitters on Wall Street.

title: Unemployment Figures
summary: The nation's unemployment rate fell to the lowest point in six years this June, while the number of workers on the payroll jumped much higher than expected. Moreover, hourly earnings posted the largest gain on record. As NPR's Jim Zarroli reports, it was enough for a campaigning President Clinton to quickly claim credit, while Wall Street reacted out of fears that inflation...and rising interest rates...are around the corner.

title: New Gov't In Haiti
summary: NPR's David Welna reports on the problems facing Haiti's new government as it tries to rebuild the Caribbean nation's economy. Since taking office five months ago, President Rene Preval has had little success overcoming eighty percent unemployment, high inflation, and a barely functioning infrastructure. The congress has not approved a privatization plan, which is holding up hundreds of millions of dollars in loans. All of this, combined with a crime wave and

title: Brazil Economy
summary: NPR's Nina Teicholz repotrs from Rio de Janeiro that Brazil's effort to end hyper-inflation has created other problems: increasing business bankruptcies, rising unemployment, and a serious loss of consumer buying power. Economists lay much of the blame on the so-called Real (r

title: Unemployment
summary: NPR's Jim Zarroli reports on the surprisingly strong figures for job growth in the month of May, and what they might mean for the nation's economy...and the fall election. May's job figures were more than twice what analysts expected, and sent some investors scrambling in response to fears that interest rates will rise to ward off inflation.

title: The Consumer Price Index
summary: was released today and showed inflation on the rise.

title: The U.S. just experienced its slowest annual sales of homes since 1995
summary: week. the average rate on a 30-year mortgage passed the 7% mark, before dropping slightly this week to 6.96%. Experts say rates of 6-7% are the new normal. "Economic and monetary policy uncertainty and inflationary concerns will likely keep mortgage rates elevated for the near future," said Mortgage Bankers Association President and CEO Bob Broeksmit in a statement. Meanwhile, prices on homes that did sell have been very high, as more sales

title: Fed's Departing Vice Chair On Stocks, The Federal Debt And Transparency
summary: the stock market compared with the average of when interest rates were 6 percent or 7 percent will say values are very high. But we don't think we're in a situation where we have an inflationary bubble or an unsustainable set of prices in the asset markets, but we don't comment on that very much and I shouldn't go on. On criticism that the Fed should be more transparent The transcripts

title: Paul Krugman's Prescription For A 'Depression'
summary: depression." On when the federal government should address its deficit "If you get to the point where the economy is strong enough that the Federal Reserve is starting to raise interest rates so as to avoid an inflationary overheating, that's a time when you can in fact start to do some fiscal austerity and it won't cause higher unemployment, because the fed can simply put off those interest rate hikes. But we're

title: Imf And Brazil
summary: they are more exposed to risk in Brazil than in any other emerging market. Of particular concern is the possibility that Brazil's leaders will have to devalue the nation's currency, which would lead to an inflationary spiral and trigger problems with other Latin American currencies. To help head off any problems, which should come to a head after this Sunday's presidential election in Brazil, International Monetary Fund officials are trying to put

title: Interest Rates
summary: NPR's John Ydstie reports the Federal Reserve policymakers raised a key short-term interest rate today by a quarter point to 5.5% The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee is actually changing the target for the Fed Funds Rate...that's the interest rates banks charge each other for overnight loans. The Fed hopes the small increase will slow the economy enough to avoid inflationary pressure.

title: Greenspan Talks
summary: NPR's John Ydstie reports that Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan delivered an upbeat assessment of the economy today. In testimony before Congress, Greenspan said the economy hasn't been generating the signs of inflationary pressure that undermined past expansions.

title: . Market
summary: NPR's Jim Zarroli reports that prices on the stock market plunged today. The Dow Industrial Average fell more than 130 points, or 2.3% The S&P 500, a broader index, was off even more, 2.5%. Investors are worried that robust employment numbers from last Friday could feed an inflationary pickup.

title: Cost Of Popcorn Spikes
summary: The cost of popcorn is up. Jim Boyd, a movie theater owner in Van Wert, Ohio, says he pays 50 percent more for a bag of popcorn than he did at the beginning of 2008. Farmers Dale and Charles Profit say their fertilizer costs have increased. And Will Weaver, CEO of Weaver Popcorn, in Van Buren, Ind., says he is looking at every aspect of his business to find ways he can cut costs.

title: The word 'recession' is coming up more frequently. But there can be silver linings
summary: NPR's Michel Martin speaks with Michelle Singletary, personal finance columnist for The Washington Post, about why a recession doesn't have to be so scary.

title: Some governors are turning voluntary land conservation into a culture war item
summary: Voluntary conservation is embraced by some farmers who get payments. But some governors are comparing Biden's new plan to up conservation goals to a government takeover.

title: Challenges low income countries are facing
summary: NPR's Ailsa Chang speaks with Dr. Atul Gawande of USAID about the challenges facing low-income countries as they tackle continued COVID surges, a lack of monkey pox vaccines and climate disasters.

title: Unionization is catching on among undergraduate student workers
summary: Student workers are the latest in the wave of unionization nationwide. Students from several private universities have unionized, and undergrads from dozens of other schools are making plans to do so.

title: What one oil historian thinks about oil companies reporting record profits
summary: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks with oil historian Gregory Brew about the record profits being reported by oil companies.

title: Helium prices are blowing up. Here's what is causing the increase
summary: When it comes to the global helium supply this year, "everything that could go wrong has gone wrong," says one analyst. That affects everything from birthday balloons to superconducting magnets.

title: Median Net Worth Declines
summary: The Fed's report in June said the net worth of Americans showed the biggest decline since 2002. Scott Hoyt, senior director of consumer economics at Moody's Economy.com, says when the value of assets fall, it makes it harder to reach financial goals.

title: What to know about Argentina's eccentric, conservative new president-elect
summary: An ultra-conservative economist, known for his temper and eccentricities, will take over Argentina's presidency in December amidst one of the worst economic downturns in decades.

title: Violent Crackdowns In Venezuela Severely Impacted Maduro's Opposition
summary: NPR's Robert Siegel speaks with Carlos, an actor and tour guide in Caracas, Venezuela. Carlos used to protest daily against President Nicholas Maduro's government. Now, those protests have dissipated, opposition leaders have been imprisoned, and Carlos, who earlier said that he did not want to leave Venezuela, is looking for a job abroad.

title: Fed Signals It May Take More Steps To Boost Economy
summary: Federal Reserve policymakers signaled on Tuesday that they're prepared to take additional steps to support the economy if necessary. The Fed has been holding interest rates near zero, but growth hasn't returned and unemployment remains high.

title: This is why it's still so expensive to rent a car
summary: Renting a car has never been more frustrating for a lot of customers. The industry started to see cracks during the pandemic due to supply chain backlogs, but those problems persist.

title: What The Federal Reserve May Be Planning For The Future
summary: NPR's Ailsa Chang speaks with economist Julia Coronado about the Federal Reserve's recent efforts to protect the economy and what plans does it have moving forward.

title: What the leading presidential candidates have to say about soaring housing costs
summary: Millions of people are struggling with the record high costs of renting or buying a home. That's made housing a top concern for voters.

title: What oil companies gain from the landmark climate bill
summary: Some say benefits for fossil fuel companies in Congress's climate change legislation weaken its impact. NPR's Michel Martin speaks with energy historian Gregory Brew about the bill.

title: In Zimbabwe, Doctors Are Taking To The Streets To Strike Over Diminishing Pay
summary: When Robert Mugabe was ousted in 2017, Zimbabweans thought the new administration would right the economic ruin. But instead, life has gotten worse. Doctors are striking over diminishing pay.

title: Germany, China and Russia react to Trump's victory
summary: The world is reacting to former President Trump's election victory. In Russia, analysts are thinking about how it might affect U.S. military aid to Ukraine.

title: How interest rates are affecting house buyers and sellers
summary: The housing market is one of the sectors of the economy most directly affected by the Federal Reserve raising interest rates. Those increases are affecting people trying to buy and sell homes.

title: U.S. Officials Warn Of Possible Coup In Venezuela
summary: Venezuela is in freefall. There's no food, medicine or power. The president is accusing the U.S. of instigating the shortages through what he claims is economic sabotage. The U.S. is warning of a possible coup in the South American nation.

title: With Biden's help, House Democrats are working to win over voters ahead of midterms
summary: President Biden traveled to Philadelphia to pump up lawmakers who are on the ballot this fall and are already getting an earful from constituents about higher costs for gas and groceries.

title: Recycling Industry Slows As Consumers Shop Less
summary: At Paper Fiber Americas, a wastepaper exporter in Portland, Ore., tons of cans, beer boxes, newsprint and plastic jugs form a huge mountain of recycling. John Dryden, who runs the exporting operation, says when he looks at the large pile of trash, he normally sees money. But recently, Dryden's business has been transformed by countless consumers who are opting to buy less. Those small, individual choices to hold off on certain purchases put fewer

title: California hopes to lure insurance companies back with extreme regulation overhaul
summary: California's wildfire risk is so high, numerous insurance companies have left the state. Now, the insurance commissioner has presented a new plan to entice them to return.

title: When will it stop being the 'pandemic economy?'
summary: NPR's Ailsa Chang talks with economist Austan Goolsbee about what it will take for the U.S. to recover from the unique economic challenges posed by the pandemic.

title: U.S. companies seem to be doing fine — but below the surface, there are warning signs
summary: Despite a lot of economic uncertainty, most companies in the S&P 500 did better in the second quarter than Wall Street expected. But there were signs the economy is starting to slow down.

title: For Tumultous Venezuela, An Easy 2018 Political Transition Looks Unlikely
summary: After another year of political and economic turmoil in Venezuela, guest host Ray Suarez speaks with Phil Gunson of the International Crisis Group about what 2018 could bring for the country.

title: Amid Downturn, Net Worth Takes A Beating
summary: The long economic downturn has left most Americans feeling poorer. And, in fact, according to Roben Farzad of Bloomberg BusinessWeek, they are. He tells Robert Siegel that per capita net worth has taken a beating, driven down primarily by falling housing prices.

title: The federal government helps tribal communities in Alaska move to higher ground
summary: The federal government is giving millions of dollars to tribal communities in Alaska to help them move to higher ground. The relocations are necessary because of the effects of climate change.

title: Despite Maduro's Unpopularity, Venezuela's Opposition Isn't A Shoo-In For Election
summary: Venezuelans are suffering under increasing shortages of food, medicine, and other basics. But growing anger from this has not translated into greater success at the ballot box for the opposition.

title: Struggling Sears May Tap Rivals in Revival Strategy
summary: It was once the largest retailer in the U.S., but Sears, Roebuck and Co. has been struggling for years as competitors such as Home Depot and Lowe's lured customers away. Now, in an effort to boost its bottom line, Sears may actually turn to its rivals for help. The company's chairman says it may be that some of the chain's most popular and exclusive brands will be sold outside of Sears

title: Federal Reserve latest: Powell testifies and governing board nominees are reviewed
summary: Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell testified before a House committee Wednesday. Meanwhile, a Senate panel reviewed several nominations to the Fed's board of governors, including the first Latina.

title: Democrats are embracing the police, but can that distract from crime in their cities?
summary: Democrats are embracing the police during the midterms. But can they distance themselves from crime in Democrat-run cities, such as Philadelphia, Pa.?

title: Food Shortages At The Heart Of Venezuelan Economic And Political Crisis
summary: Venezuela's economic and political crisis continues to plague the country. Over the past two months, 40 people have died in clashes. NPR's Michel Martin speaks with Reuter's reporter Girish Gupta.

title: Attitudes about the economy are much better than they were this time last year
summary: The economic outlook has improved considerably from this time last year, when many forecasters were predicting a recession in 2023.

title: The White House has a new public engagement advisor. Here's her plan
summary: Keisha Lance Bottoms is the new White House senior advisor for public engagement. The former Atlanta mayor begins her job at a time when President Biden's approval ratings are at an all-time low.

title: Ethiopia and Nigeria are floating their currencies. Could instability follow?
summary: NPR's Adrian Ma speaks with Cerian Richmond Jones of The Economist about the decision by Nigerian and Ethiopian governments to float their respective currencies.

title: Child hunger is expected to worsen
summary: NPR's Ailsa Chang speaks with pediatrician Dr. Megan Sandel about how the pandemic has exasperated child hunger in the country and could worsen as pandemic-relief programs run out.

title: Sen. Joe Manchin pulled the plug on major spending to address climate change
summary: Sen. Joe Manchin, D-W.Va., dashed Democrats' hopes of major climate spending in the budget reconciliation. Here's what that means for the country's ability to bring down carbon emissions.

title: Interest rate hikes widen the wealth gap, an economist argues
summary: NPR's Michel Martin talks with Darrick Hamilton, economics professor at The New School in New York City, about the relationship between interest rates and wealth inequality.

title: Unemployment down as UAW and Hollywood actors return from strikes
summary: U.S. employers added 199,000 jobs in November, as the unemployment rate fell to 3.7%. The resolution of the UAW and Hollywood actors' strikes helped to boost those numbers.

title: CEO Salaries Continues To Rise
summary: The economy is still on the road to recovery, but CEOs seem to be doing just fine. A new study reveals the median pay for a CEO at a top-200 company last year was $10.8 million, up 23 percent in just a year. P.J. Joshi of The New York Times discusses why CEOs get the ever-bigger bucks while most workers are barely staying even.

title: Average Wages Are Going Up, And So Are Prices
summary: Employers have figured out what it takes to find workers in a tight job market: higher wages. Restaurant wages have increased almost 10% over the last year, which could affect menu prices.

title: Crude Oil Prices Top $58 a Barrel
summary: Crude oil prices set a new record Friday, closing above $58 a barrel. Traders have been pushing up the price of oil on concerns that strong global demand may strain limited refining capacity.

title: U.S. to release 50 million barrels of crude oil from the reserve to lower gas prices
summary: The Biden administration is tapping into the country's emergency petroleum reserves in a bid to bring down high gas prices. But it's not clear how successful that strategy will be.

title: No Social Security COLA In 2010
summary: The Social Security Administration says there will be no cost-of-living increase next year for more than 50 million recipients of Social Security. The announcement comes a day after President Obama called for $250 payments for seniors, veterans, retired railroad workers and people with disabilities.

title: Will Trump pay to save the Colorado River? Locals are worried
summary: President Biden helped avert a crisis on the Colorado River by paying farmers and cities $28 million in IRA funds to not take water out of the river. States fear a future without those payments.

title: Argentina's far-right president has had some economic success. But analysts are wary
summary: Argentina's ultra libertarian president is raking up economic successes at home and stirring up controversy abroad.

title: How to get your finances ready for a possible recession
summary: NPR's Cheryl Corley speaks with Washington Post personal finance columnist Michelle Singletary about how to manage large debt loads as interest rates increase and prepare for a possible recession.

title: Answering Listeners' Questions On The Debt Ceiling
summary: The debate over whether to raise the federal debt ceiling is multifaceted — and often confusing. So, All Things Considered invited listeners to tell us what they would like to understand better. Robert Siegel puts a few of their questions to economist and former Federal Reserve Governor Larry Meyer and NPR congressional correspondent Andrea Seabrook.

title: House Democrats are hoping to pass spending package and infrastructure bill
summary: Democratic leaders in the House are still hoping to vote on a large part of President Joe Biden's domestic agenda Friday. But as the clock winds down, they're struggling to round up the votes.

title: Letters: Brazil's Economy; Howlin' Wolf
summary: NPR's Robert Siegel and Mary Louise Kelly read from listeners' e-mails about Brazil's economy; a 50 Great Voices piece about Howlin' Wolf; and the movie Harold and Kumar Go to White Castle.

title: Unaffordable rental market hits record heights
summary: A Harvard University study shows that people across all income levels have been affected by rising rents. That means Americans are handing over a bigger portion of their paychecks to housing costs.

title: Democrats pull off climate, health and tax bill in weekend sessions
summary: Senate Democrats passed a spending bill which would attempt to tackle climate change, the high cost of prescription drugs and lower the deficit by roughly $300 billion.

title: Ponzi Schemes Proliferate Beyond Madoff
summary: The times may be bad for many of us, but the recession has been good for the legacy of Charles Ponzi. Ponzi didn't invent the scam that bears his name, but he took it to new heights. In 1920, he defrauded investors of some $7 million before he was arrested. Since Bernard Madoff's arrest in December for allegedly bilking investors out of $50 billion, authorities have continued to uncover one suspected Ponzi scheme

title: Mugabe Makes First Speech Since Election
summary: Zimbabwe's leader, Robert Mugabe, delivers his first major speech since the country's disputed presidential vote three weeks ago. He marked Zimbabwe's Independence Day by accusing thieves of trying to unseat him.

title: Kroger and Albertsons CEOs face Senate lawmakers over their planned merger
summary: The CEOs of Kroger and Albertsons face Senate lawmakers to publicly address concerns about their planned $25 billion merger that would combine the two largest U.S. supermarket chains.

title: When Scientists Give Up
summary: Ian Glomski thought he was going to make a difference in the fight to protect people from deadly anthrax germs. He had done everything right — attended one top university, landed an assistant professorship at another. But Glomski ran head-on into an unpleasant reality: These days, the scramble for money to conduct research has become stultifying. So, he's giving up on science. And he's not alone. Federal funding for biomedical research has declined

title: Addressing The Threat Of Deflation
summary: As central banks continue to slash interest rates almost to zero, prices can plummet. It creates a liquidity trap, as it did in the 1930s and in Japan during the 1990s. Harvard economist Kenneth Rogoff outlines what deflation could mean for modern America.

title: Trump's raise worries about the global economy — and the Fed
summary: The International Monetary Fund is projecting higher prices and slower economic growth in the U.S. as a result of President Trump's trade war. That's a tough spot for the Federal Reserve.

title: Why the U.S. cares about the war in Ukraine
summary: Six months into the war in Ukraine, why should the U.S. continue to care and spend billions of dollars on the war when Europe is so ambivalent? And what do U.S. officials see as the end game?

title: White House Council of Economic Advisers head on the economic issues the U.S. faces
summary: NPR's Ailsa Chang talks with Cecilia Rouse, chair of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, about President Biden's Federal Reserve nomination and the economic challenges the country is facing.

title: At Least 15 Killed, Dozens Injured As Venezuelan Protests Swell
summary: Students and members of the middle class have taken to the streets in Venezuela, protesting a worsening economy and food shortages. AP bureau chief Joshua Goodman reports on the unrest from Caracas.

title: 'No Reasonable Prospect' Of Dollar Losing 'Reserve' Status, Geithner Says
summary: As Chinese President Hu Jintao begins a state visit to Washington, among the issues on a lot of minds are the value of the Chinese yuan and whether Hu would like to see the dollar lose its status as the world's reserve currency. In a conversation today with Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner, All Things Considered co-host Robert Siegel asked about Hu's statement in The Wall Street Journal that "the current international currency

title: U.S. employers added 263,000 jobs in September
summary: U.S. employers added 263,000 jobs in September — a modest slowdown from August. The job market is still tight, though, as the unemployment rate dipped to 3.5%.

title: At Davos, U.S. Economic Recovery Widely Lauded
summary: Audie Cornish talks with Kenneth Rogoff, professor of economics at Harvard University, and former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund.

title: The state of the State of the Union address
summary: President Biden will give his State of the Union address on Tuesday. But with more ways to communicate with the public, does the annual televised address carry the same weight it used to?

title: Democrat senators kick off weekend debate over climate, tax and health bill
summary: The Senate is starting debate on a major Democratic bill to address climate change, drug prices, the deficit and more. It would be a major win for President Biden to carry into the midterms.

title: Biden's week: COVID, a 'historic' agreement and the GDP
summary: The Democrats' agenda that looked stalled from the outside just got a major boost. Is there still time for things to turn around for Biden and his party before midterm elections?

title: Interest rates are unlikely to drop, Fed chair indicates to Senate committee
summary: Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell told a Senate committee that he and his colleagues are in no hurry to cut borrowing costs, so long as the job market is holding up and prices continue to climb.

title: Biden administration to lift some travel restrictions and remittances on Cubans
summary: The White House announced it will lift some of the Trump era restriction on travel and remittances on Cubans. Hit hard by COVID and other missteps, the Cuban economy is barely functioning for many.

title: Economists Brace for Worsening Subprime Crisis
summary: Jose Pomales stands on his back porch with his 7-year-old son, Jordan, and looks out over his big backyard. Eight years ago, he moved into his modest ranch house in Boston's Hyde Park neighborhood and has since spent time and energy on landscaping and fixing it up. Pomales has a solid job with a local housing authority, and he and his wife's combined income is around $65,000 a year. He

title: People struggle with higher food prices in Egypt's economic crisis
summary: The war in Ukraine and Egypt's own economic crisis have made it hard for people in Cairo to afford food. Charities are straining to meet the need.

title: House OKs Bill Curbing Alternative Minimum Tax
summary: The House of Representatives has passed a bill intended to keep millions of middle-class taxpayers from having to pay the Alternative Minimum Tax. That tax is intended for the very wealthy. The bill pays for the change by raising tax rates on private-equity and hedge-fund managers.

title: What we can learn from the U.K.'s economic fallout
summary: NPR's Ailsa Chang talks with Simon Johnson, a professor at MIT's Sloan School of Management, about warning signs for the U.S. from the U.K.'s political and economical upheaval.

title: Voters in Argentina back its ruling party's candidate in presidential elections
summary: The ruling party in Argentina did surprisingly well in this weekend's presidential election, coming in first despite facing the worst economy in decades.

title: How Republicans Plan To Win Back Control Of Congress In The 2022 Midterms
summary: Republicans believe the 2022 midterms will hinge on President Biden's handling of the economy. Strategists and campaign officials say voters across the U.S. rank higher prices above all other issues.

title: How The Tooth Fairy Helps Explain The Rising Cost Of Parenting
summary: How much is a tooth worth to the tooth fairy and has that price changed over time? This is a silly question of course, but the answer is serious. It gives us a way to understand how the costs of parenting have changed over time.

title: Minimum Wage Increases Across U.S. Affects Wide Range Of Workers
summary: This week, 21 states and the District of Columbia raised their minimum wage, affecting an estimated 3.1 million workers, from a Dairy Queen owner in South Dakota to a hotel banquet server in Alaska.

title: U.S. Downplays Human Rights in Vietnam Leader's Visit
summary: Vietnamese Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung is being received at the White House Tuesday. There are calls on Capitol Hill for President Bush to make human rights a focal point of talks, but the administration is playing up economic cooperation.

title: Fed Chair Jerome Powell told lawmakers that interest rates will likely fall this year
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell says the central bank will likely start cutting interest rates this year. But he offered no firm timetable, saying the economic outlook is still uncertain.

title: Gasoline prices have fallen recently, but experts warn that prices could rise again
summary: Gasoline prices have fallen sharply and are now below $4 a gallon in many parts of the country. But analysts warn that prices could tick up again if drivers set aside their newfound gas-saving habits.

title: Venezuelan Opposition Moves On Maduro Recall Amid Food Crisis
summary: NPR's Kelly McEvers talks to Girish Gupta of Reuters about the growing food crisis in Venezuela, and the state of the recall effort against President Nicolas Maduro.

title: The Cycle Of Fear Over Rising Gas Prices
summary: Headlines this week screamed about rising gas prices — as they have many times before. In the past 15 years, Dick Polman, national political writer for the Philadelphia Inquirer, estimates he's covered spiking gas prices a dozen times. The story, he tells NPR's Linda Wertheimer, almost always has the same narrative arc.

title: Stay-At-Home Improvement: DIY Builders Help Drive Up Lumber Prices
summary: For years, Matt Harris dreamed about building a treehouse out behind his back fence in Knoxville, Tenn. He never got around to it, though, until the pandemic hit. "It was just a matter of finding time," Harris says. "And that didn't come until everything kind of shut down for a little bit." When the coronavirus canceled youth sports for the season, Harris suddenly found his weekends free. And his children — ages 8, 7 and

title: Week In Politics: Wisconsin Protest
summary: Host Michele Norris speaks with our political commentators — E.J. Dionne of the Washington Post and Brookings Institution, and Linda Chavez, a syndicated columnist and chairman of the Center for Equal Opportunity — about the ongoing protests surrounding planned budget cuts in Wisconsin.

title: Hawaii to Begin Capping Wholesale Gas Prices
summary: Hawaii has moved to limit wholesale gas prices, beginning next week, as consumers suffer high fuel costs. Traders drove the price of oil to $68 a barrel on some markets Thursday before levels eased back. Hawaii, which has all of its oil shipped in, has some of the highest gas prices in the nation -- prices for regular unleaded hover at $3.10. The recent move is the first such effort in the United States since

title: Zimbabwe's Finance Minister Discusses How To Fix Country's Crumbling Economy
summary: NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with Zimbabwe's Finance Minister Mthuli Ncube about his mission to turn around his country's crumbling economy.

title: Biden adviser Gene Sperling sees U.S. hope and resilience despite shrinking economy
summary: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with White House senior adviser Gene Sperling about Thursday's new GDP numbers and the health of the U.S. economy.

summary: NPR's Audie Cornish speaks with Oxford economist Mahir Rasheed about Americans spending money this holiday season despite poll numbers saying people are worried about their future economic state.

title: Far surpassing expectations, the U.S. added a whopping 339,000 jobs in May
summary: U.S. employers added a whopping 339,000 jobs in May, far more than forecasters had expected. The unemployment rate, which is compiled from a separate survey, rose to a still-low 3.7%.
